proxyLocation: top-center of the yellow table
utilizationMethod: Grip the narrow cylindrical neck of the spray bottle between thumb, index and middle finger, ignoring the trigger. The hard, smooth plastic tube beneath the nozzle gives a rigid round shaft that can be pivoted like a fat marker; the nozzle tip can be treated as the drawing point while the larger body simply rests above the hand, approximating light pen-like motions.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This marker serves as a drawing tool.
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: The marker would feel moderately lightweight
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel the cylindrical body with smooth rounded edges and consistent 1.7cm diameter.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user will employ a precision tripod grip (thumb, index, and middle finger) around the 1.7 cm-diameter cylindrical body, similar to holding a pen. While drawing, the hand pivots mainly at the wrist and fingers, producing small, controlled translations and rotations of the shaft. The marker stays rigid in the hand; its low mass offers minimal inertial resistance, so strokes feel light and responsive. The felt tip makes intermittent contact with virtual surfaces, giving the sense of point-contact feedback but no deformation of the barrel. Users may also rotate the marker between fingertips to change stroke angle or flip it in the hand to recap it, but the object itself does not visibly compress or change shape.

proxyLocation: top-right of the yellow table
utilizationMethod: Pinch the upper rim of the can with a tripod grip so that only a small arc of the rim sits between the fingertips. Although the diameter is larger, the smooth aluminum cylinder and light weight allow wrist-led sketching motions that imitate broad marker strokes; the rim edge functions as the writing tip.

proxyLocation: standing upright near the top-center of the yellow table
utilizationMethod: Hold the narrow neck of the bottle with thumb and index finger and twist the cap or nozzle to copy the uncapping motion of the paint tube, then shift your grip to wrap the whole hand around the plastic body and squeeze rhythmically on the slightly flexible walls; the audible air displacement and mild give of the plastic replicate the feel of expelling paint from a tube.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This oil paint tube serves as a paint storage. Users would grasp it to squeeze out paint.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel the distinctive flattened, elongated cylindrical shape
virtualObjectInfo.hardness: User should feel the body as pliable and squeezable, deforming under pressure but maintaining structural integrity.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The tube is first grasped with a light power or precision grip near the threaded neck to uncap it (thumb and index finger twist while the other fingers stabilize the body). During paint dispensing, the dominant hand shifts to a power squeeze grip that envelopes the flattened, pliable body; the palm and all fingers apply progressively increasing pressure from the sealed end toward the opening while the tube is aimed downward. The metal/foil body locally collapses under finger pressure, providing noticeable compliance and slowly re-expands if released. The resistance increases as paint volume decreases, giving tactile feedback that content is being expelled.

proxyLocation: top-center of the yellow table

virtualObjectInfo.usage: It serves as an artistic tool for painting. Users would make controlled strokes across canvas surfaces.
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: The brush would feel lightweight.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel the cylindrical handle (1cm diameter) with smooth, rounded edges.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The brush is held in a relaxed tripod precision grip on its slim (≈1 cm diameter) wooden handle, usually 2–8 cm behind the ferrule. The wrist and fingers guide fine, sweeping or dabbing motions over a virtual canvas. Users occasionally roll the handle between thumb and index finger to rotate the bristle orientation for line-weight control. The handle feels rigid and light; only the soft bristle tip bends, giving slight springiness on contact but no discernible deformation of the handle.

utilizationMethod: Pinch the rigid USB-A plug between thumb and index finger and allow 10–15 cm of the flexible cable to dangle forward.  The small plug provides a slender handle you can roll, and the light, swinging cable imitates a soft brush tip making contact as you tap or sweep across an imagined canvas.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: It serves as an artistic tool for painting. Users would make controlled strokes across canvas surfaces.
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: The brush would feel lightweight.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel the cylindrical handle (1cm diameter) with smooth, rounded edges.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The brush is held in a relaxed tripod precision grip on its slim (≈1 cm diameter) wooden handle, usually 2–8 cm behind the ferrule. The wrist and fingers guide fine, sweeping or dabbing motions over a virtual canvas. Users occasionally roll the handle between thumb and index finger to rotate the bristle orientation for line-weight control. The handle feels rigid and light; only the soft bristle tip bends, giving slight springiness on contact but no discernible deformation of the handle.

proxyLocation: lower right of the yellow table
utilizationMethod: Pull out about 10 cm of the narrow metal tape and hold the extended strip lightly between thumb and index finger, 2–3 cm from the case.  The thin, rigid strip acts like a brush handle and its slight springiness at the free end mimics the subtle flex of bristles when you dab against a surface.

proxyLocation: standing upright near the top-center of the yellow table
utilizationMethod: Grip the narrow neck/trigger section as you would the paint-roller handle and swing the bottle in long arcs. Because most of the mass is in the liquid-filled reservoir above your hand, you feel a mild top-heavy inertia similar to a loaded roller head. The smooth cylindrical body also lets you lightly press and ‘glide’ the base against the table to mimic the moment when the foam roller contacts a wall.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This paint roller serves as a painting tool for covering large surfaces efficiently.
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate weight with a slight top-heavy feel.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a ergonomic cylindrical shape fitting naturally in the palm.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The roller is grasped with a full power grip around the ergonomic handle; when covering large areas the off-hand may steady the frame, turning the interaction into a two-handed tool use. Strokes involve broad shoulder and elbow movement, rolling the top-heavy cylinder along surfaces in long, continuous arcs. As the arm pushes and lifts, the roller head spins freely, generating a mild gyroscopic feel and a repeating vibration or rumble as ‘paint’ is laid down. Users also perform brief wrist flicks to lift the roller off the surface, perceiving sudden loss of contact and the weight of the roller shifting to the handle. The rigid metal frame does not deform, but the foam cylinder compresses slightly when pressed harder, providing compliant feedback.

proxyLocation: top-right of the yellow table surface
utilizationMethod: Hold the can horizontally between thumb and fingers and push it forward so it rolls along the tabletop. The freely rolling cylinder, combined with the can’s modest weight, recreates the sensation of the paint roller head spinning while you guide it across a surface.
